meta/config.notes: Path-keyed Firestore seed. Replace demo IDs with real userId/childIds as needed.

parentProfile.instructions: Please read each statement and choose the answer that best describes how you typically behave as a parent. There are no right or wrong answers.

items.text: I am responsive to our child's feelings or needs.
I use physical punishment as a way of disciplining our child.
I take our child's desires into account before asking the child to do something.
When our child asks why they have to conform, I state: "Because I said so," or "I am your parent and I want you to."
I explain to our child how we feel about the child's good and bad behavior.
I spank when our child is disobedient.
I encourage our child to talk about their troubles.
I find it difficult to discipline our child.
I encourage our child to freely express themself even when disagreeing with parents.
I punish by taking privileges away from our child with little if any explanation.
I emphasize the reasons for rules.
I give comfort and understanding when our child is upset.
Item text incomplete in source (commotion about something).
I explode in anger towards our child.
Item text incomplete in source (threaten ... when he/she is being disobedient).
I state punishments to our child and do not actually do them.
Item text incomplete in source (show respect for our ...).
I have warm and intimate times together with our child.
I punish by putting our child off somewhere alone with little if any explanation.
I help our child to understand the impact of behavior by encouraging our child to talk about the consequences of his/her own actions.
I scold or criticize when our child's behavior doesn't meet our expectations.
I explain the consequences of the child's behavior.
I slap our child when the child misbehaves.

parentProfile.scoringNotes: Compute validated subscale means once item-to-subscale mapping is finalized.

temperamentProfile.instructions: Please read each statement about your child's reactions to a number of situations over the past six months. Decide whether it is a 'true' or 'untrue' description of your child.

items.text: Seems always in a big hurry to get from one place to another.
Gets quite frustrated when prevented from doing something they want to do.
When drawing or coloring in a book, shows strong concentration.
Likes going down high slides or other adventurous activities.
Is quite upset by a little cut or bruise.
Prepares for trips and outings by planning things they will need.
Often rushes into new situations.
Tends to become sad if the family's plans don't work out.
Likes being sung to.
Seems to be at ease with almost any person.
Is afraid of burglars or the "boogie man."
Notices it when parents are wearing new clothing.
Prefers quiet activities to active games.
When angry about something, they tend to stay upset for ten minutes or longer.
When building or putting something together, becomes very involved in what they are doing, and works for long periods.
Likes to go high and fast when pushed on a swing.
Seems to feel depressed when unable to accomplish some task.
Is good at following instructions.
Takes a long time in approaching new situations.
Hardly ever complains when ill with a cold.
Likes the sound of words, such as nursery rhymes.
Is sometimes shy even around people they have known for a long time.
Is very difficult to soothe when they have become upset.
Is quickly aware of some new item in the living room.
Is full of energy, even in the evening.
Is not afraid of the dark.
Sometimes becomes absorbed in a picture book and looks at it for a long time.
Likes rough and rowdy games.
Is not very upset at minor cuts or bruises.
Approaches places they have been told are dangerous slowly and cautiously.
Is slow and unhurried in deciding what to do next.
Gets angry when they can't find something they want to play with.
Enjoys gentle rhythmic activities such as rocking or swaying.
Sometimes turns away shyly from new acquaintances.
Becomes upset when loved relatives or friends are getting ready to leave following a visit.
Comments when a parent has changed their appearance.

temperamentProfile.scoringNotes: Compute validated dimension means once item-to-dimension mapping is finalized.
